text:
What’s that bright thing in the sky?
Is it a blazing chariot?
An all-seeing eye? Maybe a burning ball of gas?

At different points in history, humans have 
believed the sun to be all of these things.
They may not have agreed on what the sun was,

but ancient cultures recognized 
its power to sustain life,

so it was appropriately held in a 
place of honor in most mythologies.

Whether people thought it was a divine being 
or a nuclear fusion factory, which we now

know to be the case, the stories all had one 
lesson in common: don’t look directly at it.

Energy from the sun gives heat, offers a 
bright reprieve from the darkness of night,

and serves as the base
for our entire food chain.
Basically, the sun is central to so many myths

because it provides all the energy we 
need to live. But it makes you wonder.
Where does all that energy even come from?

Well, let’s have fellow astronomer Matt 
O’Dowd from PBS Digital’s Space Time

explain a little about the
source of the sun’s power.

The Sun is a gigantic nuclear 
reactor, as is every star.

And I do mean gigantic. It's the same as 
every nuclear bomb on the planet went off

roughly 20 million times every second. It's 
been doing that for 5 billion years so far,

with another 5 billion to go. The secret 
to this incredible energy production

comes from the most famous
equation of all time:
Einstein's E = mc².

This tells us that mass is just
another form of energy

and that every little bit of mass 
contains an enormous amount of energy.

And that's the type of energy 
released in the center of the Sun.

The tiny nuclei of the tiniest atom - hydrogen 
- are smashed together at incredible speeds,

allowing them to overcome
their natural repulsion

and stick together due
to the strong nuclear force.

The result is a nucleus of helium plus a LOT 
of energy. This is a bit of stellar alchemy:

the elements of the periodic table 
are forged in the hearts of stars,

although most of the interesting ones get 
made by stars much bigger than our sun,
before being blasted out in supernova explosions.

The energy produced in these 
fusion reactions takes the form of

gamma ray light. This light slowly makes its 
way out of the super-dense interior of the Sun.

It takes 10s of thousands of 
years for each photon of light

to bounce its way out. And then takes 
about eight minutes to reach the earth

once it escapes. So the warmth you 
feel on your face when you step out

into a  summer day was actually 
produced in the core of the Sun
before the dawn of human civilization.

And since that dawn, cultures 
have been worshiping the sun
and its light as a powerful deity.

Think about it. The world seems to 
come alive when the sun is in the sky,

and its reliable return every day 
provides a sense of order to the universe.

Of course, when ancient Indian cultures 
in the Vedic period about 3000 years

ago looked at the Sun, they knew nothing 
about the strong nuclear force. Instead,

they saw the highest representation 
of Agni, the Vedic god of fire.
Often depicted with two heads and riding a ram,

Agni was one of the most powerful Vedic gods, 
second only to Indra, the god of the heavens.

In the other levels of his power, Agni 
existed on Earth as regular fire and in

the sky as lightning. In his triumvirate 
form, he came to represent the connection
between the mundane and the divine.

Just like the fire and sun he personified, 
Agni was feared as an agent of destruction,
but also revered for his ability to nourish.

But Agni wasn’t always pleased by 
his association with destruction.
In one story from the Vedas, a demon asked Agni

to confirm his rightful betrothal 
to Puloma, wife of the sage Bhrigu.

It was a complicated situation, and Agni could 
neither confirm nor deny the demon’s claim,
so the demon stole Puloma away.

She made it back okay, but Bhrigu 
still cursed Agni to devour and destroy

everything in his path. Enraged, Agni protested 
by withdrawing all of his fire from the world,

including the fire that humans 
used to sacrifice to the gods.

Obviously, this would not do, so Brahma, 
the supreme creator of the universe,

altered the curse so that Agni’s fire 
would purify everything he touched.

Agni isn’t the oldest solar deity — it’s likely 
impossible to know who that first one was.

The Vedic culture was just one of many 
who devoted a lot of time, energy,
and resources to worshiping the sun.

The Incas who lived in modern day 
Peru from the 12th to 16th centuries

incorporated the Sun in so 
many aspects of their culture,
from holidays to agriculture to politics.

Their sun god, Inti, was one of 
their most powerful deities, again,

second only to his father, 
the creator god Viracocha.

The Incan royal family was said to 
be directly descended from Inti,
so his temples were the most grand.
The Temple of the Sun in the capital city Cuzco

was made of ornately carved stone and 
filled with extravagant gold objects,

all of which was plundered when the Spanish 
conquered the Inca Empire in the 1500s.

Inti was honored every year with a 
week-long festival called Inti Raymi.

The festival includes fasting, 
sacrificing scores of animals,

parading decorated statues of Inti, 
and of course singing and dancing.

It’s a party, after all, but it was 
also meant as an appeal to Inti.
The festival,  which is still held today,

happens In June, around the southern 
hemisphere’s winter solstice.

In their celebration they were begging Inti 
to return to them in the darkest time of year

Of course, not all solar 
deities were depicted as male.

In Japanese shinto religion, 
Amaterasu is considered
the most powerful kami, or divine  spirit.

She is the ruler of the Takama no Hara, the 
high celestial plain where all the kami live.

Born from the left eye of her father 
Izanagi as he purified himself in a stream,

Amaterasu is also said to be the 
ancestor of the Japanese ruling family.

In one myth, Amaterasu hides in a 
cave after the storm god Susanoo

pulls some distasteful 
younger brother shenanigans.
Without Amaterasu’s warming light, the world
fell into decay and evil spirits roamed the Earth.

The other kami tried everything they could 
think of to draw Amaterasu out of the cave,

from using roosters to trick her into thinking 
it was dawn to bribing her with sparkly jewels.

She was eventually lured out 
of hiding by the kamis’ raucous

laughter as they watched the goddess 
Amenouzume perform a naughty dance.

In Baltic mythology, the sun was represented by 
Saule, the mother and ruler of the heavenly beings

who determined the well-being 
of all life on earth.

Depicted as a blond woman 
wearing a golden shawl and crown,

Saule lived in a palace at the end of the sea, 
where she tended a garden of golden apples.

According to legend, Saule in her divine radiance
would ride across the sky in a chariot pulled by

two tireless white horses who didn’t 
sweat. Her daughters were the planets

and her husband was the moon. Though in 
some stories, Saule and the moon are divorced

because he decided to pursue the goddess of 
dawn, aka the morning star or the planet Venus.

Saule was far from the only solar deity to ride 
a vehicle across the sky. The Greek gods Helios

and Apollo were both shown riding 
a chariot through the heavens.

The Egyptian sun god Ra was 
said to ride in a solar barge

during the day. At night, he sailed through the 
underworld until he returned to the sky in the

east. Cave carvings from the neolithic 
and bronze ages depicting the Sun on

a ship passing through stars show that the concept
of a solar barge has existed for millennia.

Given how important the sun 
was to these ancient cultures,

it’s no surprise that a solar 
eclipse, a phenomenon where the moon
blocks the light of the Sun from our earthly view,

would be a dramatic and meaningful 
event. As Ra passed through the Egyptian

underworld in his boat, the evil 
god Apep would try to devour him.
Eclipses happened when he succeeded,
but Ra always managed to escape.

Plenty of other cultures explained 
eclipses as something eating the sun.

In Vietnamese mythology, that 
creature is a frog or toad.

In ancient China, it was a 
dragon. In Hindu mythology,

the god Rahu was beheaded, 
and he swallowed the sun

as his severed head flew through the 
air. In various parts of the world,

including parts of China, South America, 
and even at the Griffith Observatory in LA,

it’s customary to make loud 
noises like banging pots and pans

to scare away the animal or demon trying 
to eat or steal the sun during an eclipse.

But to the Fon people of modern day Benin, a 
solar eclipse was cause to celebrate, not fear.

Also known as the Dahomey, the Fon 
believed that a supreme being named

Nana Buluku created the universe 
and gave birth to Mawu and Lisa.

Mawu created the Earth with the help of a 
great snake and then invited her brother Lisa

to help her populate it with their children: 
gods, goddesses, plants, animals, and humans.

The humans treated poor Mawu so terribly that 
she fled to the sky and inhabited the moon.

But, she took pity on them and 
sent her brother/baby daddy Lisa

to teach the humans how to build shelter, 
use tools, and farm. When he was done,

he went up to the sky and inhabited 
the sun to be close to his sister/wife.

When Mawu first went to visit 
Lisa, she blocked his sunlight,

but it was okay because the fruit 
of that union… was literal fruit.

They were the seeds that humans needed 
to plant once they mastered farming.
And now when there’s a solar eclipse,

the Fon who hold onto the old ways hope 
there might be another gift from above.

From fiery gods of destruction to sweet 
life givers who farm apples and protect

orphans, the sun has been a central figure 
in some of the world’s most enduring myths.

That’s because, as humans, there would be no 
life without that nuclear force in the sky.

I guess that makes it pretty important… 
but in the grand scheme of things,
it’s still just a boring, middle-aged G-type star.
To learn just how not-special the sun is,

check out our collab episode with
PBS Space Time
about galactic habitable zones,

featuring your other favorite 
astrophysicist host: Matt O’Dowd.

I’ll also be there to answer the question: 
if there are aliens in the Milky Way,
where should they be?
While you’re there, be sure to check out the other episodes.

Space Time explores the outer 
reaches of space, the craziness of astrophysics,

and the possibilities of sci-fi, and anything 
else you can think of beyond Planet Earth.
